node.title: [PR fix] Caching updates
node.body: Reopening this since https://github.com/dswcodes0/StatChat/pull/29 was accidentally merged in

node.bodyText: If there's an error you should probably return here and not continue with the rest of the code. This way you don't need the validUser variable.
Nice use of .some! What's the difference between some and using something like a for-loop?
I'm a little confused by this comment. Is it possible some of the variable names changed since you first wrote it?

What would happen in this case, if we searched: "alice" -> "bob" -> "alice" -> "caleb" -> "dan"?
The most recently searched should be alice, caleb, and dan.
With this logic, it looks like we will instead save bob, caleb, and dan.
some returns true if even one value meets the condition while a for loop is for more general iterating things

yes, this was for a different version of the code, thank you for pointing it out:
new comment:          //assigned the stats for the new user as the user1.stats to user later.

This looks good! It'd be super helpful in the future if you added a thorough test plan (ex. all the cases you tried) - or even better, unit tests.
Approved (I can't do this in the UI since I opened this PR)
The previous location of the catch block was a bit better, since it wrapped around the piece that we expect to throw an error.

It would be good to move "3" to a constant at the module level. Right now it's kind of a magic number. 1) In case we need to reference it later. 2) Giving it a descriptive name will readers understand what exactly "3" is.
Even better explanation: https://chat.openai.com/share/64952937-bd11-49ad-bab5-22074a49b488

node.title: Farming kicks
node.body:
Did something with the `blocksClicked` field in the `checkForBlockChange` method to fix this disconnect while farming:
```
Netty Client IO #4@21376" daemon prio=5 tid=0xda nid=NA runnable
  java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
      at java.util.ConcurrentModificationException.<init>(Unknown Source:-1)
      at java.util.TreeMap$PrivateEntryIterator.nextEntry(Unknown Source:-1)
      at java.util.TreeMap$ValueIterator.next(Unknown Source:-1)
      at io.github.moulberry.notenoughupdates.miscfeatures.ItemCooldowns.checkForBlockChange(ItemCooldowns.java:173)
      at io.github.moulberry.notenoughupdates.miscfeatures.ItemCooldowns.processBlockChangePacket(ItemCooldowns.java:167)
      at net.minecraft.client.network.NetHandlerPlayClient.handler$bjb000$handleBlockChange(MixinNetHandlerPlayClient.java:123)
      at net.minecraft.client.network.NetHandlerPlayClient.func_147234_a(NetHandlerPlayClient.java:688)
      at net.minecraft.network.play.server.S23PacketBlockChange.func_148833_a(SourceFile:40)
      at net.minecraft.network.play.server.S23PacketBlockChange.func_148833_a(SourceFile:13)
      at net.minecraft.network.NetworkManager.channelRead0(NetworkManager.java:151)
      at net.minecraft.network.NetworkManager.channelRead0(NetworkManager.java:54)
      ```
I've tested it, this fixes it for me.

node.title: Gateway dependency
node.body:
🛠 DevTools 🛠

[![Open in GitHub Codespaces](https://github.com/codespaces/badge.svg)](https://codespaces.new/daniellok-db/mlflow/pull/9991?quickstart=1) #### Install mlflow from this PR ``` pip install git+https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow.git@refs/pull/9991/merge ``` #### Checkout with GitHub CLI ``` gh pr checkout 9991 ```

### What changes are proposed in this pull request? This PR updates `_capture_modules.py` to detect when `import mlflow.gateway` is called, and append it appropriately to the resulting `requirements.txt` file ### How is this PR tested? - [x] Existing unit/integration tests Existing unit tests work: ``` $ pytest tests/utils/test_requirements_utils.py ... 20 passed, 32 warnings in 7.96s ``` - [x] New unit/integration tests Added a new test: ``` tests/utils/test_requirements_utils.py::test_capture_imported_modules_includes_extras PASSED [100%] ``` - [x] Manual tests Tried saving a model with `mlflow[gateway]` as a dependency, then switching to an environment that doesn't have `mlflow[gateway]` installed. Expectation here is that it should give me some helpful error message that tells me to install it. I guess the behavior here isn't ideal because it implies that mlflow is not installed at all. I think it should be quite easy to change the `installed_version` param to be more helpful in this case though (see comments below) ### Does this PR require documentation update? - [x] No. You can skip the rest of this section. - [ ] Yes. I've updated: - [ ] Examples - [ ] API references - [ ] Instructions ### Release Notes #### Is this a user-facing change? - [x] No. You can skip the rest of this section. - [ ] Yes. Give a description of this change to be included in the release notes for MLflow users. #### What component(s), interfaces, languages, and integrations does this PR affect? Components - [x] `area/artifacts`: Artifact stores and artifact logging - [ ] `area/build`: Build and test infrastructure for MLflow - [ ] `area/docs`: MLflow documentation pages - [ ] `area/examples`: Example code - [x] `area/gateway`: AI Gateway service, Gateway client APIs, third-party Gateway integrations - [ ] `area/model-registry`: Model Registry service, APIs, and the fluent client calls for Model Registry - [x] `area/models`: MLmodel format, model serialization/deserialization, flavors - [ ] `area/recipes`: Recipes, Recipe APIs, Recipe configs, Recipe Templates - [ ] `area/projects`: MLproject format, project running backends - [ ] `area/scoring`: MLflow Model server, model deployment tools, Spark UDFs - [ ] `area/server-infra`: MLflow Tracking server backend - [ ] `area/tracking`: Tracking Service, tracking client APIs, autologging Interface - [ ] `area/uiux`: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server - [ ] `area/docker`: Docker use across MLflow's components, such as MLflow Projects and MLflow Models - [ ] `area/sqlalchemy`: Use of SQLAlchemy in the Tracking Service or Model Registry - [ ] `area/windows`: Windows support Language - [ ] `language/r`: R APIs and clients - [ ] `language/java`: Java APIs and clients - [ ] `language/new`: Proposals for new client languages Integrations - [ ] `integrations/azure`: Azure and Azure ML integrations - [ ] `integrations/sagemaker`: SageMaker integrations - [ ] `integrations/databricks`: Databricks integrations #### How should the PR be classified in the release notes? Choose one: - [x] `rn/none` - No description will be included. The PR will be mentioned only by the PR number in the "Small Bugfixes and Documentation Updates" section - [ ] `rn/breaking-change` - The PR will be mentioned in the "Breaking Changes" section - [ ] `rn/feature` - A new user-facing feature worth mentioning in the release notes - [ ] `rn/bug-fix` - A user-facing bug fix worth mentioning in the release notes - [ ] `rn/documentation` - A user-facing documentation change worth mentioning in the release notes

node.bodyText: tried to follow the format of the databricks special casing above, but not sure if it's necessary since this really only affects gateway
the value here is kind of arbitrary—it doesn't really get used except in requirements_utils.py:429 but it's hardcoded there too. maybe i should const it?
i felt a little weird about this, let me know if there's a better way to get the gateway extra recognized as a proper package.

if we want to keep the one liner i can make this something like
return sorted([
    _get_pinned_requirement(pkg) for pkg in packages 
    if pkg != "mlflow[gateway]" 
    else _get_pinned_requirements("mlflow", extras=["gateway"]
)])

reusing the gateway detection logic from here
as mentioned in the PR description, i could maybe change installed_version here to be something like mlflow=={version} rather than None, would that be more helpful?
I like the current code. It looks more readable than one-liner.

The error message would look like this?
mlflow (current: uninstalled, requirement: mlflow[gateway])
yup exactly, i'm wondering if people will get confused and think that mlflow is not installed at all

Another option is refactor _get_pinned_requirements  to accept a package requirement like mlflow[gateway] and remove the extras argument. This allows us to remove if package == "mlflow[gateway].
diff --git a/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py b/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py
index 9233e52a7..cdbbbb26b 100644
--- a/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py
+++ b/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py
@@ -462,18 +462,20 @@ def _strip_local_version_label(version):
         return version
 
 
-def _get_pinned_requirement(package, version=None, module=None, extras=None):
+def _get_pinned_requirement(req, version=None, module=None):
     """
     Returns a string representing a pinned pip requirement to install the specified package and
     version (e.g. 'mlflow==1.2.3').
 
-    :param package: The name of the package.
+    :param req: The package requirement (e.g., 'mlflow' or 'mlflow[gateway]')
     :param version: The version of the package. If None, defaults to the installed version.
     :param module: The name of the top-level module provided by the package . For example,
                    if `package` is 'scikit-learn', `module` should be 'sklearn'. If None, defaults
                    to `package`.
     :param extras: A list of extra names for the package
     """
+    req = Requirement(req)
+    package = req.name
     if version is None:
         version_raw = _get_installed_version(package, module)
         local_version_label = _get_local_version_label(version_raw)
@@ -492,8 +494,8 @@ def _get_pinned_requirement(package, version=None, module=None, extras=None):
         else:
             version = version_raw
 
-    if extras:
-        return f"{package}[{','.join(extras)}]=={version}"
+    if req.extras:
+        return f"{package}[{','.join(req.extras)}]=={version}"
     return f"{package}=={version}"
I think overall looks great! Just left a few nits :)

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                        input_example=([1, 2, 3]),
          
          
            
                        input_example=[1, 2, 3],

We can update this to one line though
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    if package == "mlflow[gateway]":
          
          
            
                        pinned_requirement = _get_pinned_requirement("mlflow", extras=["gateway"])
          
          
            
                    else:
          
          
            
                        pinned_requirement = _get_pinned_requirement(package)
          
          
            
                    pinned_requirement = _get_pinned_requirement("mlflow", extras=["gateway"]) if package == "mlflow[gateway]" else _get_pinned_requirement(package)
I like this, we could use it to detect other extras in the future.
I think it's fine, we also use it in _capture_modules.
Maybe update package_name to be mlflow[gateway]?

Maybe update package_name to be mlflow[gateway]?

+1
Left some comments, otherwise LGTM!
this makes sense, i went with this solution in the end!

@harupy I ended up refactoring the _get_pinned_requirement function to remove the extras param, so I had to edit this callsite as well (looks like it was the only other one using the extras param). Let me know if it looks alright!
Yes, looks good to me!

for some reason the old line (import mlflow.gateway) was causing a test failure.
It looks like it was overriding the mlflow variable name, making line 557 below fail (mlflow.__version__):
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/daniel.lok/mlflow/mlflow/pyfunc/__init__.py", line 594, in _warn_dependency_requirement_mismatches
    mismatch_info = _check_requirement_satisfied(req_line)
  File "/Users/daniel.lok/mlflow/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py", line 557, in _check_requirement_satisfied
    and installed_version == mlflow.__version__
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'mlflow' referenced before assignment

Changing this to from mlflow import gateway seems to fix
Interesting. mlflow is imported in the top level in requirements_utils.py.

yeah i'm not sure about the cause either—you can try this example to repro:
import datetime

def test(should_import):
    if should_import:
        import datetime.datetime
    print(datetime.__version__)

test(False)

Or here is one that actually does something when test(True):
import importlib

def test(should_import):
    if should_import:
        import importlib.metadata
    print(importlib.__name__)

test(False)
https://chat.openai.com/share/372cbd76-25c3-4fef-840b-2b826d44588b

import mlflow.gateway

is equivalent to:
mlflow = ...
mlflow.gateway = ...

?
This seems like a good python quiz.
Let's use from mlflow import gateway :)

Hahaha yeah it's weird. It has something to do with the conditional, it does something even when the code inside the if block will never be executed:
import importlib

def test():
    if False:
        import importlib.metadata
    print(importlib.__name__)

test()
it also seems to matter that it's in a function, because the following has no problems:
import importlib

if False:
    import importlib.metadata
print(importlib.__name__)
but anyway yeah i think in the end the problem can be avoided with from mlflow import gateway because then there's no reassignment to the mlflow variable, just gateway.
LGTM!
This will not work in cases like dimension SIM(N, *) where dimension contains variable
Let's add a test that only uses --legacy-array-syntax, but not --implicit-typing, that way we isolate these options and ensure they work correctly in isolation.

Let's remove this file, and instead test the integration_tests file, which is the same file. That way we ensure exactly the same code will give an error message by default, but works with --legacy-array-sections.
Remove the white space?
I think this looks great. I left a few minor comments.
Aah yes, I will do that.
Initially it was not indented properly. I guess after rebasing on top of main, extra tab space got added.

node.title: Add Pagination for Posts
node.body:
<!-- Issues that this pull request closes. -->
Closes #1046
<!-- Should look like this: `Closes #1, #2, #3.` . -->

### Summary
<!-- Please describe the changes you made. -->

Add pagination for Posts Block.

Developing notes:
 - It seems that Dynamic Content collides with the counting mechanism. It needs some investigation on the cause.

### Screenshots <!-- if applicable -->

![image](https://github.com/Codeinwp/otter-blocks/assets/17597852/50b16af4-5f71-4991-8582-96d6b4a46ae7)

![image](https://github.com/Codeinwp/otter-blocks/assets/17597852/c94e6b7e-e16a-40d9-a7b3-f105e8a9d602)


https://github.com/Codeinwp/otter-blocks/assets/17597852/9bdbff2e-11cb-457d-8271-2a2572167e12

----




### Test instructions
<!-- Describe how this pull request can be tested. -->

1. Insert a Post Block
2. Enable pagination and customize it.

<!--
#### Query
```javascript
new QueryQA().select('blocks').run()
```
-->

---- 

### Checklist before the final review

- [ ] Included E2E or unit tests for the changes in this PR.
- [x] Visual elements are not affected by independent changes.
- [x] It is at least compatible with the [minimum WordPress version](https://wordpress.org/plugins/otter-blocks/).
- [x] It loads additional script in frontend only if it is required.
- [x] Does not impact the [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/vitals/).
- [x] In case of deprecation, old blocks are safely migrated.
- [x] It is usable in Widgets and FSE.
- [x] Copy/Paste is working if the attributes are modified.
- [x] PR is following [the best practices]()

node.bodyText: @HardeepAsrani, any idea if we can do the page counting to be nicer?

We can use query->max_num_pages; to get the maximum numbers. I'd avoid using two WP_Query calls. We used get_posts because it was more efficient when not used but now that we're using pagination, we can consider using WP_Query too.

Hey, I was just testing it on an instance to see the flow and pagination doesn't work:


Regardless the page, it loads the same posts.
NIT: You can fix the type, it should be retrieve_posts
Left a small NIT but it looks good. It worked well when tried it locally. We can put it through QA and remove the QA-related code afterwards.
@HardeepAsrani, do you think it is worth keeping this for one release? I am considering the possibility of a slow rendering issue, which can help us confirm it on user websites.
Might be worth testing this on our end with a dummy website with 1000s of posts, but we don't need to put it in prod given the number doesn't make much sense unless you can test before/after results.

@HardeepAsrani, do you see something wrong with this? When added to Home page, the link is something like this https://cycleadvertisement.s2-tastewp.com/page/2/ and is not working. If you put the block on a post page, the link will be like https://cycleadvertisement.s2-tastewp.com/index.php/2023/10/12/post/page/2/ and is working.

@Soare-Robert-Daniel When you're going to that URL, I suppose it's redirecting you to 404? Or is it still opening the home?
Also, is it the sam eissue with Qubely?

Yes. With one mention that Qubley works when the link is not in a pretty format (I made an update also for us). For other formats, it is not working. It gives the same 404.
This 404 is in WP Taste, on my Local instance, they work without any issues. So I suspect some hosting setting might be in play.
Might be some issue with nginx/htaccess configs maybe, then we can skip that part and live with it for this version.

node.title: ci: check mergable by label
node.body:
This ci blocks PRs by the labels on hold and do not merge yet, so it cannot accidentally be merged by not reading the labels

Code is slightly copied from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71502652/prevent-merging-of-branch-conditionally-based-on-label

node.bodyText:
In VSCode this currently shows following error, and I don't know why and what is broken 🤔
Nested mappings are not allowed in compact mappings at line 27, column 13:

        if: contains(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name, 's: on hold')
            ^
fixed by applying actions/runner#1019 (comment)
I would merge them into one Job so that our job list does grow that much. And it shouldnt matter that much either way which label blocks it exactly.

I thought about this as well 🤔 But on the other side it makes it more clear to a contributor why exactly the CI fails
If both are merged into on job, we cannot diff anymore and cannot show a specific message

I thought about this as well 🤔 But on the other side it makes it more clear to a contributor why exactly the CI fails

I think the label names are self explanatory especially in combination with "blocked by label" CI.

If both are merged into on job, we cannot diff anymore and cannot show a specific message

The label being added or removed already has its own github notification, there is no need for a bot to add more (especially if it works for members only).
The : in s: on hold makes trouble, so I'm testing endsWith instead
Have you tried running this without the token?
I don't see where is permission is used. Is that something implicit?

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            name: Check mergable by label
          
          
            
            name: PR-Labels

or
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            name: Check mergable by label
          
          
            
            name: PR Labels

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                  - name: Fail if PR is labeled by a blocking label
          
          
            
                  - name: Check for blocking labels

AFAICT these two should be unrelated.
https://docs.github.com/en/webhooks/webhook-events-and-payloads?actionType=synchronize#pull_request
These are especially for rebasing all current PRs, so they get checked when this PR gets merged
So should we remove those at a later point in time?

I don't think the effort is worth it 😅
It just works with or without them

node.title: Nisyad/modify map per class
node.body: This PR modifies the return output for `MeanAveragePrecision` for per class metrics. Return output as a dict with label_ids as keys.

node.bodyText: with missing classes in targets or prediction?
this sort got run by len(result['map_per_class']) times

nit:
# for line 41
self._update_label_ids(predictions)
self._update_label_ids(targets)

def _update_label_ids(self, items: List[Dict[str, torch.Tensor]]]) -> None:
       for item in items:
            self._label_ids.update(item['labels'].tolist())
maybe check the Len equality
There is reset and clone you might want to make sure they are working properly after adding this, with unit tests.
https://github.com/Lightning-AI/torchmetrics/blob/3b3b997487fea2e05a65d81abc23a7ebef3371f1/src/torchmetrics/metric.py#L658
updated - separated into two tests
thanks. updated
updated
updated - added a unit test to verify label_ids set across batches.

Clone test
a = metric()
a.update(...., ....)
b = a.clone()
assert b.calculate() == a.calculate()
Reset test
data1(10 classes)
data2(2 classes)
a = metric()
a.update(data1)
a.reset()
a.update(data2)
b=metric()
b.update(data2)
assert a.calculate() == b.calculate()
slightly confusing "# Wrong" comment

Updated.
Now using existing *-labels attributes of the Metric class to track all 'seen' labels. Added unit tests.
Fixed and updated.
where is the clone tested?

Can you have multiple test cases covering different scenarios:
more classes before reset
more classes after reset
..
Wrt info on parametrized tests:
https://chat.openai.com/share/9841c3a6-3be4-4450-b3a5-b6d7cbe81250
More test cases pls. Same with reset

Any reason still keeping this behavior:

the base class returns list, while this class returns dictionary for result['map_per_class']?

I thought returning as a dictionary with label info might make the tagwise result clearer for the end user. But on second thoughts, this may not still be a great idea. We would need to make the tagwise results of all other metric also as dict-style otherwise the user might be more confused.
So assuming we maintain the base class behavior, do we still need unit tests for reset() and clone() because we are not adding new states or modifying anything else. Basically, there is no PR.

I remember in our last discussion, we agreed the need of dictionary output is mostly one kind of client need.
It does have the benefit wrt clarity, but there are ways doing it without making it a dictionary making it behave differently than the base class.
If no code change is needed, you can still check in the tests which could be helpful
